READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 397, 680, 412]]<|/det|> Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 412, 306, 426]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 426, 480, 440]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 440, 480, 454]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 453, 361, 467]]<|/det|> DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 478, 265, 492]]<|/det|> Answer both questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 492, 744, 506]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of one hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 505, 863, 533]]<|/det|> You are expected to record all your observations as soon as these observations are made, and to plan the presentation of the records so that it is not necessary to make a fair copy of them. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 532, 705, 547]]<|/det|> You are reminded of the need for good English and clear presentation in your answers. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 558, 344, 571]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 571, 730, 585]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 594, 769, 609]]<|/det|> Additional answer paper and graph paper should be used only if it becomes necessary to do so. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 619, 576, 633]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 633, 722, 648]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 688, 861, 812]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 68, 702, 87]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 97, 91, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 655, 115]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium of a metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 139, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 126, 732, 144]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a metre rule with a \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass attached to it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 156, 175, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 156, 520, 174]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 183, 764, 450]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 469, 507, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 498, 876, 532]]<|/det|>
The distance between the end of the rule and the string loop from which mass P is suspended is \(x\), as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 543, 876, 577]]<|/det|>
The distance between the same end of the rule and the string loop suspended from the rod of the clamp is \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 588, 165, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 588, 574, 605]]<|/det|>
Position mass P so that \(x\) is approximately \(30 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 617, 165, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 617, 705, 635]]<|/det|>
Without changing \(x\), adjust the position of the rule until it balances.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 648, 165, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 648, 415, 665]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\) and \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 691, 875, 707]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ...............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 736, 875, 752]]<|/det|>
<form>y = ...............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 750, 876, 768]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 141, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 67, 826, 87]]<|/det|>
Change x. Adjust the position of the rule until it balances. Measure and record x and \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 98, 467, 116]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 127, 386, 145]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 497, 876, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 524, 136, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 524, 173, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 524, 608, 544]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(y\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 524, 876, 543]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 554, 173, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 554, 435, 573]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 554, 876, 573]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 583, 173, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 583, 579, 602]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[472, 774, 875, 794]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 805, 875, 824]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 821, 876, 838]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 141, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 67, 687, 87]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(y\) and \(x\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 98, 520, 116]]<|/det|>
\[y = A x + B\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 127, 384, 144]]<|/det|>
where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 155, 645, 174]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in **(c)**(iii), determine the values of \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 170, 331, 188]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 289, 873, 307]]<|/det|>
<form>A = ...............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 319, 875, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>B = ...............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 335, 876, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 363, 139, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 363, 319, 381]]<|/det|>
Theory suggests that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 384, 527, 415]]<|/det|>
\[A = \frac{2M}{3M + Q}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 421, 589, 440]]<|/det|>
where \(M\) is the mass of the metre rule and \(Q = 0.100 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 451, 346, 469]]<|/det|>
Determine a value for \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 465, 719, 484]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to three significant figures. Include an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 616, 876, 635]]<|/det|>
<form>M = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[791, 645, 876, 664]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 68, 702, 87]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 98, 92, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 818, 116]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the motion of a magnet connected to some springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 138, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 127, 173, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 125, 816, 144]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two magnets A and B and three connected springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 156, 203, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 156, 755, 175]]<|/det|>
Use the tape to attach magnet A to the springs as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 183, 755, 262]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 281, 507, 299]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2.1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 310, 203, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 310, 876, 344]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2, with the N poles of magnets A and B facing each other.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 355, 740, 667]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 684, 509, 702]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2.2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 714, 203, 732]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 714, 536, 732]]<|/det|>
The distance between the magnets is \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 744, 730, 761]]<|/det|>
Adjust the height of the wooden rod until \(x\) is approximately \(7 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 774, 203, 791]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 774, 401, 791]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 817, 880, 835]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 817, 876, 835]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 67, 173, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 67, 613, 87]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of x.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 199, 876, 218]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 229, 139, 248]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 229, 176, 248]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 229, 576, 248]]<|/det|>
Pull magnet A down through a short distance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 259, 589, 278]]<|/det|>
Release the magnet. The magnet will oscillate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 288, 576, 307]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 450, 876, 469]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 479, 173, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 479, 727, 498]]<|/det|>
Reverse magnet B in the G-clamp so that its S pole is at the top.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 509, 813, 528]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of the wooden rod until \(x\) has the same value as in **(a)**(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 539, 655, 558]]<|/det|>
Determine the period \(T_{2}\) of the oscillations of magnet A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 657, 876, 676]]<|/det|>
<form>T_2 = .................................................... s [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 686, 171, 704]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 686, 329, 704]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 759, 876, 778]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 68, 175, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>
